From the MFA website http://www.mfa.org/ca...

Various reviews, a full mixture...64% rating at
http://www.rottentoma...

I'm thinking Khadak must mean "color of water" in Mongolian

Khadak by Peter Brosens and Jessica Woodworth (Belgium/Germany/Netherlands, 2006, 104 min.). Set in the frozen steppes of Mongolia, this "entrancing looking and lushly scored magical-realist fable" (Leslie Felperin, Variety) tells the epic story of Bagi, a young nomad confronted with his destiny to become a shaman. When a plague strikes the local animals, the nomads are forced to relocate to desolate mining towns. Bagi saves the life of a beautiful coal thief, Zolzaya, and together they reveal the plague to be a lie designed to eradicate nomadism, and a sublime revolution ensues. Called a "trippy spectacle" by Matt Zoller Seitz of The New York Times, the film presents an unusual story set in a spectacular location. In Mongolian with English subtitles.

This is a later movie, 8pm, but it's under 2 hours. I think we'll give Brown Sugar Cafe a try afterwards for our post movie discussion. It's just on the other side of the Fens. A shorter walk than Shawarma. Link attached.
http://www.brownsugar...


MFA members, seniors, and students $8; general admission $9.
